conclusion: The problem involves determining how shadows labeled A, B, C, and D change in position and size when the light source moves to the back right.
Shadows are formed when an object blocks light from a light source, and their position and size depend on the position of the light source relative to the object.
If the light source moves, the shadow moves in the opposite direction relative to the light source's movement.
The size of the shadow changes depending on the distance between the object and the light source.
The image shows four objects: an apple, a piece of paper, a chicken leg, and another object casting shadows labeled A, B, C, and D respectively.
The shadows A, B, C, and D are cast to the back right of the objects due to the light source positioned at the front left.

premise: If the light source moves to the back right, shadows move in the opposite direction relative to the light source's movement.
conclusion: When the light source moves to the back right, shadows A, B, C, and D will move to the front left.

premise: The size of the shadow changes depending on the distance between the object and the light source. When the light source moves closer to the objects, the angle between the light and the horizontal line increases.
conclusion: When the light source moves to the back right and closer to the objects, shadows A, B, C, and D will become smaller.

premise: Shadows A, B, C, and D move to the front left and become smaller when the light source moves to the back right.
conclusion: A, B, C, and D move to the front left and become smaller.
